questions.text: An intellectually challenged teenager was diagnosed with a trinucleotide repeat mutation disease. On examination, his IQ is 49. He has a long face with a large mandible, everted large ears, a high-arched palate, and large testicles. What is the most likely nucleotide repeat sequence in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of fragile X syndrome. The specific trinucleotide repeat sequence in fragile X syndrome is CGG.

Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after Down's syndrome. It is due to the mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene (FMR1) located on the long arm of the X chromosome. 

It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family. The affected males are intellectually disabled, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60. Neuropsychiatric features include aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism (large testicles)
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

Other options:

Option A: CAG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Huntington’s disease, spinocerebellar ataxia 1,2,3,6,7 and spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

Option B: CTG is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in myotonic dystrophy.

Option D: GAA is the trinucleotide repeat sequence present in Friedreich ataxia.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a proctoscope. 

A lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. Proctoscopy is done as an OPD procedure to detect hemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Sims' speculum is used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele. The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualization of the vaginal walls.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with recurrent urinary tract infections, the following urographic finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole due to an obstructed (and unopacified) upper pole. This is called the drooping lily sign and is observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

This condition is characterized by an incomplete fusion of upper and lower pole moieties resulting in a variety of complete or incomplete duplications of the collecting system.

Duplex collecting systems may also be complicated by vesicoureteric reflux, obstruction, or ureterocoele.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text:
The antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV is:

HIV - Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
Foscarnet is the antiviral agent that is active against all herpes viruses and HIV.

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog. It does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase for antiviral activity. It inhibits viral nucleic acid synthesis by directly inhibiting HSV DNA polymerase and HIV reverse transcriptase.

Foscarnet is used to treat acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus (genital herpes) and varicella-zoster virus infections and ganciclovir-resistant cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is also used as an alternative agent in CMV retinitis in AIDS, and CMV viremia in bone marrow transplant recipients.

Common side effects of foscarnet include nephrotoxicity and hypocalcemia.

Foscarnet is mainly excreted by the kidneys. Therefore, dose reduction is necessary for renal impairment to avoid the accumulation of the drug and associated toxicity.

Other options:

Option B: Trifluridine is a pyrimidine antimetabolite antiviral drug. It acts against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, and CMV. It is approved for use in herpes simplex keratitis.

Option C: Acyclovir is active against herpes simplex virus -1, 2, varicella-zoster virus, Ebstein Barr virus, and partially against CMV. It is useful against a variety of herpes simplex infections like genital herpes, mucocutaneous herpes, herpes simplex encephalitis, keratitis, and chickenpox.

Option D: Famcyclovir is active against herpes simplex and herpes zoster virus. It is used as a second-line agent for genital or orolabial herpes.

questions.text: Which of the following public health centers do First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to?
questions.solution:
First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to the Community Health Centers (CHCs). 

The Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) guidelines are a code of standards for uniformity in health facilities in the Indian public health system, under the National Health Mission (NHM), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), India. It aims to provide guidance on the infrastructure, human resources, drugs, diagnostics, equipment, quality, and governance requirements for delivering health services at all levels of facilities in the system.

The 2022 edition of IPHS mainly concentrates on comprehensive primary health care, increasing the human workforce, decentralized access to healthcare, and better implementation of universal health coverage.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: 4 beds Desirable: 4 daycare beds Desirable: 4 beds

The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases
  8. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems
  9. Basic Oral Health Care
  10. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  11. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of diabetes presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement, and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. The diagnosis is _________.
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts severe joint destruction and instability, seen on (a) varus stress (b) neutral (c) valgus stress on the patient's knee joint. There is minimal pain and this indicates a neuropathic cause like Charcot arthropathy.

Charcot arthropathy is a neuroarthropathy commonly associated with diabetes.

Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot arthropathy, while tertiary syphilis was one of the common causes previously.

Though the exact pathogenesis of this disease is unclear, it is speculated that vascular, neurological, and metabolic changes associated with diabetes lead to this condition.

Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and psoriatic arthropathy present with pain.

questions.text: The structures shown in the below image are found in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows psammoma bodies. They are found in meningioma.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

Conditions associated with psammoma bodies include-

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Meningiomas.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas.

They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. The most common karyotypic abnormality is the loss of the long arm of chromosome 22. Meningiomas often express hormone receptors (eg: Progesterone), hence, they may grow rapidly in pregnancy.

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. 

The tumor spreads in a sheet-like manner along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcification. 

Other options:

Option A: Russell bodies are cytoplasmic globular inclusions that are seen in multiple myeloma.

Option C: Verocay bodies are spindle cells that are arranged to form central “nuclear-free zones” ramified by palisading nuclei and are seen in Schwanomma.

Option D: Call-Exner bodies are diagnostic gland-like immature follicles that are filled with an acidophilic material and are seen in granulosa cell tumours of the ovary.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

Miyagawa bodies Lymphogranuloma venereum 
Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies Psittacosis
Leishman–Donovan bodies Kala-azar 
Negri bodies Rabies
Guarnieri bodies Vaccinia

Henderson–Peterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum

Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes

Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency

Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

Creola bodies Asthma

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and in the pulmonary circulation.

Other options - 

Option A: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

*Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominately cause bradycardia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the lower leg as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.

Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation.

Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. His erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal X-ray shows left staghorn renal calculi. The best treatment option for staghorn renal calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Staghorn calculi is also known as triple phosphate stone. It occupies the renal pelvis and calyces.

PCNL: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pulviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Stones not responding for ESWL

Other options:

Option A: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option C: Percutaneous nephrostomy, or nephropyelostomy, is an interventional procedure that is used in the decompression of the renal collecting system.

It is done in grossly unwell patients due to sepsis secondary to an obstructive urinary tract calculi. They drain pus from the kidneys adequately with less manipulation and a lower risk of septicemia than a ureteric stent.

Option D: Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket.

Ureteroscopic stone removal using dormia basket is depicted in the image below.

questions.text: What is the sequence of pubertal changes in girls?
questions.solution:
The sequence of pubertal changes seen in girls is thelarche → pubarche → menarche.

Puberty marks the normal physiologic transition from childhood to sexual and reproductive maturity. The order of changes in puberty are: 

  1. Thelarche - It refers to breast budding, and is the first visible sign. It indicates the competency of the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis. It appears between the age of 9-11 years, and is described using Tanner staging.
  2. Adrenarche - It refers to the generation of androgens (estrogen and testosterone) from the adrenal gland. 
  3. Pubarche - It refers to the development of pubic hair, and occurs usually 6 months after thelarche. It is also described using Tanner staging.
  4. Menarche - It refers to the first occurrence of menstruation. 

Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height. This is known as growth spurt and occurs between ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.

questions.text: A patient with impaired renal function was administered desflurane for general anesthesia. Which of the following statements is true regarding this drug?

choices.text: Commonly used for induction in children

questions.solution:
Desflurane has rapid induction and recovery from anesthesia due to its low blood gas solubility.

Other options:

Option A: Desflurane is not used for induction in children as it is very pungent and may result in cough, laryngospasm, and bronchospasm.

Option C: Desflurane is not environmentally safe as it has the maximum global warming potential among inhalational anesthetics. However, N2O contributes the most to increased climate impact (99.97%) as the consumption volumes of N2O far exceed those of other anesthetic gases.

Option D: Desflurane is 17 times more potent than nitrous oxide.

questions.text: A man regularly derives sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon his partner. He would often produce cuts and cigarette burns on his partner's arms. This is best described as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of sexual sadism. It is seen more commonly in men. It develops due to early experiences of brutality in sex.

The sadist may bite, beat, whip, produce cuts or cigarette burns etc on their sexual partner. In extreme cases, the victim's nipples may be bitten off, items such as a bottle or sticks are inserted into the vagina. Blunt trauma causing fractures and rupture of internal organs may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Voyeurism - It is the act of obtaining sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option B - Fetishism - It is a form of sexual behaviour in which gratification is associated with an abnormal stimulus which may be an object, activity or part of the body.

Option D - Masochism - This is opposite to sadism. Sexual gratification is obtained by suffering the pain.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with recurrent episodes of blood in his stool. Meckel’s diverticulum is suspected. Which of the following can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tc 99m pertechnetate scanning is used to confirm the diagnosis of Meckel's diverticulum.

Other uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate include:

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging for distinguishing from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging
  • Gastric emptying studies, intestinal and rectal functional studies

questions.text: A woman is planning a trip to Morocco, which is endemic for yellow fever. As per travel regulations, she receives the yellow fever vaccine. After how many days following vaccination is she eligible to travel?
questions.solution:
This woman is eligible to travel to the endemic area 10 days after being vaccinated for yellow fever. This period is required for the majority of vaccine recipients to develop immunity.

The 17D vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, administered subcutaneously.  It is valid for a lifetime beginning 10 days after vaccination.  The incubation period of yellow fever is 3–6 days. Unvaccinated people are required to remain quarantined for 6 days (maximum period of incubation).

Related Pearl: Contraindications to Vaccines

Vaccine

Live vaccines (MMR, BCG, yellow fever,Varicella)

Pregnancy

Radiation therapy

Yellow fever

Egg allergy

BCG

Symptomatic HIV infection

Influenza, yellow fever

Egg allergy

Pertussis-containing vaccines

Evolving neurological disorders

RTS,S/AS01 is effective against P. Falciparum. Phase 3 trial of this vaccine has already been completed. There is a positive scientific opinion about its risk benefit balance and a phase 4 trial is under evaluation.

questions.text: All of the following measures are correct regarding the management of frostbite except:

choices.text: Rewarming by asking the patient to exercise is not advised
Rapid rewarming can be accomplished by immersing the foot in a warm water bath
Rubbing/friction can be used to hasten up the process of rewarming
Tetanus prophylaxis must be given as there is increased risk of tetanus in frost bite

questions.solution:
Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. Affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 min. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 
  • Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.
  • Antithrombotics, thrombolytics and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.
  • Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.
  • The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.
  • Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.

Image showing frost bite of the toes

questions.text: A patient with gastric cancer and Virchow's node developed a left-sided pleural effusion. An intercostal chest tube was inserted, and the following fluid was drained.  Which structure was likely the source of this effusion?
questions.solution:
The structure affected in this case is the thoracic duct. It drains into the junction of the left jugular and left subclavian veins.

The given image shows chyle, and the case scenario is suggestive of chylothorax secondary to obstruction of the thoracic duct by Virchow's node.

A chylothorax occurs when the thoracic duct is disrupted and chyle accumulates in the pleural space. The most common cause of chylothorax is trauma (mainly thoracic surgery), but it may also result due to mediastinal tumors. Patients present with dyspnoea and a large pleural effusion.

*Clinical note:

In gastric cancer, metastasis to the left supraclavicular lymph node causes its enlargement, and it is known as Virchow's node. The Virchow's node is closely related to the thoracic duct at the site where it drains into the venous system, therefore its enlargement can mechanically obstruct the thoracic duct.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a cause of gradual painless defective vision?
questions.solution:
Methyl alcohol amblyopia causes sudden painless onset of defective vision. It is a toxic neuropathy of the optic nerve.

Related Pearl: Causes of loss of vision

Features Cause
Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Optic neuritis
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painful loss of vision
  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball
Gradual painless diminution of vision
  • Corneal dystrophy
  • Senile cataract
  • Primary open angle glaucoma
  • Optic atrophy
  • ARMD
  • Refractive error
  • Diabetic retinopathy
Gradual painful diminution of vision
  • Chronic iridocyclitis
  • Corneal ulceration

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 3 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria demonstrates tumbling type of motility at 25 °C, but is non-motile at 37 °C?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes demonstrates tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28 °C but becomes non-motile at 37 °C. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. These rods are facultatively intracellular and move from cell to cell using the host cell actin framework. It can grow at low refrigeration temperatures. They show tumbling motility at 25°C. But, at 37°C, it is non-motile because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C.

The image below shows the tumbling motility of L. monocytogenes.

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling Motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork Screw T.pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility at different temperature) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky Trichomonas
Gliding Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with 16 weeks of gestation presents with cramping abdominal pain followed by the passage of fleshy mass per vaginum. The pain subsided following the expulsion. On examination, the uterus appeared smaller with the os closed and the bleeding had stopped. Ultrasound reveals an empty uterine cavity. This is a case of ____________ miscarriage.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of complete miscarriage.

Expulsion of products of conception, en masse, is called a complete miscarriage.

Features:

  • Subsidence of abdominal pain
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus is smaller
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • USG - empty uterine cavity

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A: In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • The uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Well-formed gestation ring
  • Fetal cardiac motion
  • Blighted ovum

Option C: In inevitable miscarriage, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

Option D: In missed miscarriage, the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period

Features: The patient usually presents with features of threatened miscarriage followed by

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • Cessation of uterine growth
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac

In incomplete miscarriage, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity

  • Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • Patulous cervical os
  • Echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity

In septic abortion, there will be clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents

Features:

  • Rise of the temperature of at least 100.4 F for 24 hours or more
  • Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge
  • Other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness.

questions.text: The given emblem shows an organization related to which organism?
questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP). Leprosy is caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

Characteristics of NLEP emblem:

  • The lotus in the NLEP emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb, a normal forefinger, and the shape of a house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and that a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of leprosy.

NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Other options:

Option A- Programme dealing with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, is National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP)

Option C and D - Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis and Leishmania donovani causes Kala-azar, which are vector-borne diseases. National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya.

questions.text: A 56-year-old​ female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Dysphagia is the most common earliest presenting symptom
The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third
Common aetiological factors are tobacco and alcohol
The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing

questions.solution:
The given barium study shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins which is suggestive of carcinoma esophagus. Dysphagia is the most common presenting symptom but is a late feature in carcinoma esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third. The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing.

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other investigations include barium swallow, which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: What is the pathological basis for the given skin finding?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

questions.text: Q. You are working as an intern in the ENT department. A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor in the child. Which of the following conditions can be ruled out in this child?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia causes inspiratory stridor. Hence, it is not considered as part of the differential diagnosis for biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

questions.text: A 33-year old P3L3 woman complained of intermenstrual bleeding. On speculum examination, a polypoid lesion was visualized in the cervix, which was confirmed with the ultrasound shown below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch with serial sonograms

questions.solution:
The above ultrasound image shows the presence of an endocervical polyp. The most appropriate treatment is avulsion using ring forceps.

Endocervical polyps are overgrowths of benign endocervical stroma covered by mucinous columnar epithelium. They appear as single, red, smooth elongated masses arising from the endocervical canal. Polyps range from a few millimeters to 2-3 cm in size and are more frequently seen in multiparas.

Endocervical polyps are usually asymptomatic, but also cause intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding or vaginal discharge. They are identified by inspection during a pelvic examination or during transvaginal sonography if they are located higher up.

They are typically benign. Premalignant or malignant transformation is rare. However, cervical cancer can also present as polypoid masses and can mimic these benign lesions.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic polyps usually don't need any intervention
  • Symptomatic:
    • Removal with ring forceps: The polyp is twisted repeatedly about the base of its stalk to strangulate its feeding vessels. With a repeated twisting, the base will narrow and avulse.
    • Removal with punch biopsy forceps for smaller polyps
    • Electrosurgical excision or hysteroscopic removal for polyps with thick stalks

After the removal of polyps, the base can be cauterized to prevent bleeding and recurrence rate. Every excised polyp should be sent for further histological examination to rule out malignancy.

questions.text: A resident is examining a patient with bilateral leg swelling below the knees. He notes that on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. What is the likely cause of the edema?
questions.solution:
Bilateral non-pitting edema in the lower limbs is suggestive of myxedema.

Pretibial myxedema is a manifestation of Grave's disease. The triad of Grave's disease is orbitopathy, goiter, and pretibial myxedema.

This change is caused due to an increased glycosaminoglycan deposition in the skin giving it an edematous appearance. Despite this appearance, the skin does not pit with pressure.

While chronic lymphangitis and acute lymphatic filariasis can also cause non-pitting edema, they usually have a unilateral/localized presentation. Nephrotic syndrome and heart failure cause bilateral pitting edema.

Causes of generalized edema include:

  • Heart failure
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Liver cirrhosis

Causes of localized edema include:

  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Chronic lymphangitis
  • Resection of regional lymph nodes
  • Filariasis

questions.text: A young man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. The biopsy of the intestine is shown below. His symptoms improved with folic acid intake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with histopathology showing partial villous atrophy with inflammation of lamina propria, and improvement with folic acid intake suggest that the patient has tropical sprue.

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious etiology. Patients present with diarrhea, steatorrhoea, weight loss, folic acid, and vitamin B12 deficiency.

The small intestinal mucosal biopsy is diagnostic and reveals partial villous atrophy and mononuclear cell infiltration in the lamina propria. 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics such as tetracycline can be given for 6 months and folic acid is often curative. A gluten-free diet doesn't improve the condition. 

Other options:

Option A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Patients present with iron deficiency anaemia, weight loss, diarrhea, and malabsorption. Biopsy reveals blunting of villi, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation propria. They respond to a gluten-free diet.

The below image shows histopathological findings seen in celiac disease.

Option B- Whipple's disease is a multiorgan disease caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterised by arthralgia, arthritis, weight loss, diarrhea,  abdominal pain, and psychiatric manifestation. The organism can be detected by tissue immunohistochemistry and tissue staining for PAS-positive macrophages.

The below image shows the PAS stain in Whipple's disease.

Option D: Short bowel syndrome occurs after the resection of various lengths of the small intestine. Patients will have diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and micro and macronutrient deficiencies.

questions.text: Which of the following is the defective DNA repair mechanism seen in patients with Severe Combined Immuno Deficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ).

Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) is a mechanism by which a group of proteins mediates the recognition, processing, and direct ligation of the ends of two DNA fragments where a double-strand break in DNA has occurred. This is in contrast to homologous repair (HR), another mechanism, where an undamaged homologous DNA template is required to replace an adjacent damaged one.

NHEJ deficiency confers combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, etc.
  • The most common form is X-linked SCID, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • other gene mutations that can be seen in SCID are JAK3, RAG1, IL-7R, etc.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

DNA damage repair type

Diseases

Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)

Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)

Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease(RS-SCID)

Defective Homologous Repair (HR)

AT-like disorder (ATLD)

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Exicision Repair (NER)

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)

Cockayne syndrome (CS)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

questions.text: eFAST is least helpful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, FAST (focussed assessment with sonography in trauma) is least useful in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma as the sensitivity of ultrasound for the detection of retroperitoneal hematomas is extremely poor. 

Computed Tomography(CT Scan) is the investigation of choice for retroperitoneal injury, but it can only be done in a hemodynamically stable patient.

FAST is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

Technique:

  • The patient is placed in a supine position
  • With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned :
    • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
    • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates Left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.
